text:
Map of NauruTree map of Nauru

The **economy of Nauru** is tiny, based on a population in 2019 of only 11,550
people. The economy has historically been based on phosphate mining. With
primary phosphate reserves exhausted by the end of the 2010s, Nauru has sought
to diversify its sources of income. In 2020, Nauru's main sources of income
were the sale of fishing rights in Nauru's territorial waters, and revenue
from the Regional Processing Centre (an offshore Australian immigration
detention facility).

Nauru is dependent on foreign aid, chiefly from Australia, Taiwan and New
Zealand.
openai_summarised_points: • The economy of Nauru is very small, with a population of only 11,550 people as of 2019.
• Historically, Nauru's economy was primarily based on phosphate mining, which was the main economic activity for many years.
• By the end of the 2010s, Nauru's primary phosphate reserves were exhausted, necessitating efforts to diversify its sources of income.
• In 2020, Nauru's principal sources of income included the sale of fishing rights within its territorial waters.
• Another significant source of revenue in 2020 was the Regional Processing Centre, an offshore Australian immigration detention facility located in Nauru.
• Nauru is heavily dependent on foreign aid, receiving substantial assistance mainly from Australia, Taiwan, and New Zealand.

text:
In the years after independence in 1968, Nauru possessed the highest GDP per
capita in the world due to its rich phosphate deposits.[_citation needed_] In
anticipation of the exhaustion of phosphate deposits, a substantial amount of
the income from phosphates was invested in trust funds aiming to help cushion
the transition and provide for Nauru's economic future. However, because of
heavy spending, including poor foreign investment, the government is
now[_when?_] facing bankruptcy. To cut costs the government called for a
freeze on wages, a reduction in public service staffing, privatization of
numerous government agencies, and closure of some of Nauru's overseas
consulates.[_citation needed_] Economic uncertainty caused by financial
mismanagement and corruption, combined with shortages of basic goods, resulted
in domestic unrest.[_citation needed_] In 2004, Nauru was faced with chaos
amid political strife and the collapse of the island's telecommunications
system. Moreover, the deterioration of housing and hospitals has
continued.[_citation needed_]

Few comprehensive statistics on the Nauru economy exist, with estimates of
Nauru's GDP varying widely. According to the U.S. State Department, Nauru's
GDP volume was US$1 million in 2004.[_need quotation to verify_] Nauru
receives about US$20 million foreign aid a year from Australia.

The nation's economy has grown significantly since 2012, with help from the
reopening of the Nauru Regional Processing Centre, funded by Australia.

The most recent 2022-23 Nauru Budget recognized expected revenues of $252.5
million and expenditure of $251.9 million (20% increase from Budget 2021–2022)
with a $549,000 surplus balance. The surplus will provide cash reserves at the
bank and help Nauru manage future economic uncertainties.
openai_summarised_points: • Following its independence in 1968, Nauru had the highest GDP per capita globally, attributed to its abundant phosphate deposits.
• Anticipating the depletion of phosphate resources, Nauru invested a substantial portion of phosphate-derived income into trust funds intended to support economic transition and future stability.
• Despite these investments, heavy government spending and poor foreign investment decisions have led Nauru to face bankruptcy, though the exact timing of this financial crisis is unspecified.

• To address fiscal challenges, the government implemented cost-cutting measures including a wage freeze, reduction of public service personnel, privatization of multiple government agencies, and closure of several overseas consulates.
• Financial mismanagement and corruption contributed to economic uncertainty, shortages of basic goods, and domestic unrest within Nauru.
• In 2004, Nauru experienced political turmoil and the collapse of its telecommunications infrastructure, alongside ongoing deterioration of housing and hospital facilities.

• Comprehensive economic statistics for Nauru are scarce, with widely varying GDP estimates; the U.S. State Department reported Nauru’s GDP as US$1 million in 2004, though this figure requires verification.
• Nauru receives approximately US$20 million annually in foreign aid from Australia.
• Since 2012, Nauru’s economy has seen significant growth, partly due to the reopening of the Nauru Regional Processing Centre, which is funded by Australia.
• The 2022-23 Nauru Budget projected revenues of $252.5 million and expenditures of $251.9 million, marking a 20% increase from the 2021–2022 budget, resulting in a surplus of $549,000.
• This budget surplus is intended to bolster cash reserves held in banks and assist Nauru in managing future economic uncertainties.

text:
Phosphate is Nauru's only export product, although the government also
receives relatively significant foreign exchange income from licensing its
rich skipjack tuna fishing grounds to foreign fishing vessels, which land an
annual average of 50,000 tonnes of Nauru zone-caught tuna overseas. In 2004
income from phosphate export was US$640,000, with Australia, New Zealand and
Japan serving as the country's major export markets. In the same year the
Nauru government budget shows that income from licensing foreign fishing
vessels was over US$3,000,000.[_citation needed_]

Nauru needs to import almost all basic and capital goods, including food,
water, fuel, and manufactured goods, with Australia and New Zealand as its
major import sources. In 2004 Nauru's imports totaled about US$19.8 million.
openai_summarised_points: • Phosphate constitutes the sole export product of Nauru, representing the primary source of export revenue for the country.
• The Nauru government also generates significant foreign exchange income by licensing its rich skipjack tuna fishing grounds to foreign fishing vessels.
• These foreign fishing vessels catch an annual average of 50,000 tonnes of tuna within the Nauru fishing zone, with the tuna being landed overseas.
• In 2004, income from phosphate exports amounted to US$640,000.
• The major export markets for Nauru's phosphate in 2004 included Australia, New Zealand, and Japan.
• In the same year, the Nauru government budget recorded income exceeding US$3,000,000 from licensing foreign fishing vessels to fish in its waters.
• Nauru is heavily dependent on imports for nearly all basic and capital goods, including essential items such as food, water, fuel, and manufactured goods.
• The principal sources of imports for Nauru are Australia and New Zealand.
• In 2004, the total value of Nauru's imports was approximately US$19.8 million.

text:
Nauru has been a cash economy since at least 2004, after the Bank of Nauru and
the Republic of Nauru Finance Corporation went bankrupt and ceased operations
in the early 2000s and the licenses of all offshore banks were revoked by the
Nauru government in 2004. Nauru uses the Australian dollar for its currency.
Most government payments are executed through electronic funds transfer.
Electronic funds transfer at point of sale was introduced in 2020. The
government is required to periodically fly in Australian currency to maintain
liquidity.

On 2 June 2015, an agency of Bendigo and Adelaide Bank, Australia's fifth
largest bank, was established in Nauru by the Department of Finance. Effective
from the end of April 2016, Westpac, one of Australia's largest banks, ceased
to have any dealings with the Nauru government. On 21 April 2016, it was
announced that the Bendigo Bank was facing pressure also to close its
operation in Nauru.

On 14 November 2023, Bendigo and Adelaide Bank announced its intention to
cease operation in Nauru by December 2024. On 24 January 2024, Nauru formally
re-established diplomatic ties with the People's Republic of China after
withdrawing recognition of Taiwan. In early March 2024, the Bank of China sent
a delegation to Nauru to discuss its banking problems. On 18 March, Bendigo
and Adelaide Bank announced its intention to delay its exit from Nauru, from
December 2024 to July 2025.
openai_summarised_points: • Since at least 2004, Nauru has operated as a cash economy following the bankruptcy and cessation of operations of the Bank of Nauru and the Republic of Nauru Finance Corporation in the early 2000s.
• In 2004, the Nauru government revoked the licenses of all offshore banks, reinforcing the cash-based nature of the economy.
• Nauru uses the Australian dollar (AUD) as its official currency for all transactions.
• The majority of government payments in Nauru are conducted via electronic funds transfer, enhancing transactional efficiency.
• Electronic funds transfer at point of sale (EFTPOS) systems were introduced in Nauru in 2020, marking a significant development in the country’s payment infrastructure.
• To maintain liquidity, the Nauru government is required to periodically import Australian currency by air.
• On 2 June 2015, the Department of Finance of Nauru established an agency of Bendigo and Adelaide Bank, which is Australia’s fifth largest bank, to operate within Nauru.
• By the end of April 2016, Westpac, one of Australia’s largest banks, ceased all dealings with the Nauru government, indicating a withdrawal of major Australian banking services.

• On 21 April 2016, it was publicly announced that Bendigo and Adelaide Bank was also facing pressure to close its operations in Nauru, signaling challenges in maintaining banking services on the island.
• On 14 November 2023, Bendigo and Adelaide Bank formally announced its intention to cease operations in Nauru by December 2024.
• On 24 January 2024, Nauru officially re-established diplomatic relations with the People’s Republic of China after withdrawing its recognition of Taiwan, marking a significant geopolitical shift.
• In early March 2024, the Bank of China sent a delegation to Nauru to discuss the country’s banking challenges, indicating potential Chinese involvement in Nauru’s financial sector.
• On 18 March 2024, Bendigo and Adelaide Bank announced a delay in its planned exit from Nauru, extending its operational presence from December 2024 to July 2025.

text:
On October 1, 2014, an income tax was imposed in Nauru for the first time,
with high income earners paying a flat rate of 10%. The government spending in
2015 was forecast to be under US$92 million. Taxes include an airport
departure tax and a bed tax at the Meneñ Hotel. The 2007–08 Budget saw the
increase of existing excises on cigarettes and duty on imports. A tax on
sugary foods was also introduced, chiefly to help combat Nauru's diabetes
epidemic.
openai_summarised_points: • On October 1, 2014, Nauru implemented an income tax for the first time in its history, applying a flat rate of 10% specifically to high income earners.
• The government expenditure for the year 2015 was projected to remain below US$92 million.
• Nauru's taxation system includes an airport departure tax, which is levied on travelers leaving the country.
• A bed tax is imposed at the Meneñ Hotel, contributing to the country's tax revenue.
• The 2007–08 Budget introduced increases to existing excise taxes on cigarettes, as well as raising duties on imported goods.
• A new tax on sugary foods was established primarily as a public health measure aimed at addressing and mitigating Nauru's significant diabetes epidemic.

text:
Historically Nauru was regarded as a tax haven due to the operation of its
international financial centre, which offered amongst other things offshore
banking services. In 2001, Nauru was blacklisted internationally over concerns
it had become a haven for money laundering. Amendments made in 2004 abolished
Nauru's Offshore Banking sector and, as recognised in Nauru's latest anti-
money laundering and combating the financing of terrorism (AML/CFT) review,
Nauru's offshore sector is now limited to a small offshore company register.

In July 2017 the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD)
upgraded its rating of Nauru's standards of tax transparency. Nauru had been
listed alongside fourteen other countries that had failed to show that they
could comply with international tax transparency standards and regulations.
The OECD subsequently put Nauru through a fast-tracked compliance process and
the country was given a "largely compliant" rating.
openai_summarised_points: • Historically, Nauru was regarded as a tax haven primarily due to the operation of its international financial centre, which provided offshore banking services among other financial activities.
• In 2001, Nauru was blacklisted internationally amid concerns that it had become a haven for money laundering activities.
• In response to these concerns, amendments made in 2004 abolished Nauru's Offshore Banking sector entirely.

• According to Nauru's latest anti-money laundering and combating the financing of terrorism (AML/CFT) review, the country's offshore sector is now limited solely to a small offshore company register.
• In July 2017, the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) upgraded its rating of Nauru’s standards of tax transparency.
• Prior to this upgrade, Nauru had been listed alongside fourteen other countries that failed to demonstrate compliance with international tax transparency standards and regulations.
• The OECD subjected Nauru to a fast-tracked compliance process following its initial listing.
• As a result of this process, Nauru was awarded a "largely compliant" rating by the OECD, reflecting significant improvements in its tax transparency practices.

text:
Currently,[_when?_] Nauru is heavily dependent on Australia as its major
source of financial support. In 2001, Nauru signed an agreement with Australia
to accommodate asylum seekers (mostly from Iraq and Afghanistan) on the
island, in return for millions of dollars in aid. This agreement, referred to
as the "Pacific Solution", came to an end in 2007, prompting Nauruan concerns
about the future of the island's revenue. Australia has also sent financial
experts to Nauru to help the tiny nation overcome its economic problems.
However, serious questions remain about the long-term viability of Nauru's
economy, with uncertainties about the rehabilitation of mined land and the
replacement of income from phosphates.

In 2008, talks began between Australia and Nauru regarding the future of the
former's economic development aid to the latter. Nauruan Foreign and Finance
Minister Dr. Kieren Keke stated that his country did not want aid handouts.
One possible solution currently[_when?_] being explored would be for Australia
to assist Nauru in setting up a "boat repair industry" for regional fishing
vessels.
openai_summarised_points: • Nauru is currently heavily dependent on Australia as its primary source of financial support.
• In 2001, Nauru signed an agreement with Australia to accommodate asylum seekers, mostly from Iraq and Afghanistan, on the island in exchange for millions of dollars in aid.
• This agreement, known as the "Pacific Solution," ended in 2007, leading to concerns in Nauru about the future stability of the island’s revenue streams.
• Australia has deployed financial experts to Nauru to assist the nation in addressing its ongoing economic difficulties.

• Despite these efforts, significant doubts persist regarding the long-term sustainability of Nauru’s economy, particularly concerning the rehabilitation of mined land and the need to replace income previously generated from phosphate mining.
• In 2008, discussions commenced between Australia and Nauru about the future direction of Australia’s economic development aid to Nauru.
• Nauruan Foreign and Finance Minister Dr. Kieren Keke expressed that Nauru does not desire aid handouts, indicating a preference for sustainable economic solutions.

• One potential initiative under consideration involves Australia helping Nauru establish a "boat repair industry" aimed at servicing regional fishing vessels, as a means to diversify and strengthen Nauru’s economy.

text:
The Nauru detention centre was established by the Australian government, with
Nauruan agreement, in 2001 to cater for up to 800 refugees and asylum seekers
under Australia's Pacific solution. The centre is seen by Nauruans as an
important source of employment opportunities, in addition to the pledge of
A$20 million for development activities.[_citation needed_] The program was
gradually scaled back after 14 detainee deaths, multiple suicide attempts and
six referrals to the International Criminal Court.
openai_summarised_points: • The Nauru detention centre was established in 2001 through an agreement between the Australian government and the government of Nauru.
• The centre was designed to accommodate up to 800 refugees and asylum seekers as part of Australia's Pacific Solution policy.
• Nauruans regard the detention centre as a significant source of employment opportunities within the country.
• Alongside employment, the Australian government pledged A$20 million for development activities in Nauru linked to the detention centre arrangement.
• The detention centre program was gradually scaled back following serious incidents, including 14 detainee deaths and multiple suicide attempts.
• Additionally, six referrals related to the detention centre were made to the International Criminal Court, contributing to the reduction of the program.

text:
* GDP: purchasing power parity \- US$60 million (2001 est.)
* GDP per capita: purchasing power parity \- US$5,000 (2001 est.)
* Inflation rate (consumer prices): -3.6% (1993)
* Budget: revenues: US$23.4 million; expenditures: US$ million (1995/96)
* External debt: US$33.3 million
* Economic aid \- receives around US$2.25 million from Australia (1996/97 est.)
* Currency: Australian dollar

The fiscal year runs from July 1 to June 30.
openai_summarised_points: • The Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of Nauru, measured by purchasing power parity, was estimated at US$60 million in 2001.
• The GDP per capita of Nauru, based on purchasing power parity, was approximately US$5,000 in 2001.
• The inflation rate, as measured by consumer prices, was recorded at -3.6% in the year 1993, indicating deflation during that period.
• For the fiscal year 1995/96, Nauru's government budget revenues amounted to US$23.4 million; however, the expenditures figure is unspecified in the available data.
• Nauru's external debt was reported to be US$33.3 million, reflecting the country's outstanding financial obligations to foreign creditors.
• In the fiscal year 1996/97, Nauru received economic aid totaling approximately US$2.25 million from the government of Australia.
• The official currency used in Nauru is the Australian dollar, facilitating monetary transactions and economic activities.
• Nauru’s fiscal year spans from July 1 to June 30, defining the period for its governmental financial accounting and budgeting.

text:
* Labour force are mainly employed in mining phosphates, public administration by RONPhos, education and transport
* In 2004, the unemployment rate was close to 90%. In February 2008, foreign affairs minister Dr. Kieren Keke stated: "We have got a major unemployment crisis in front of us." By 2011, the unemployment rate had decreased to 23%.
* Main industries are phosphate mining, offshore banking, coconut products
* Electricity production (fossil fuels) and consumption are around 30 GWh (2000)
* Agriculture is not a major employer, coconuts are the main produce
openai_summarised_points: • The labour force in Nauru is primarily employed in phosphate mining, public administration through the Republic of Nauru Phosphate Corporation (RONPhos), education, and transport sectors.
• In 2004, Nauru experienced an unemployment rate close to 90%, indicating a severe employment crisis.
• By February 2008, the unemployment situation remained critical, with Foreign Affairs Minister Dr. Kieren Keke publicly stating, "We have got a major unemployment crisis in front of us."
• By 2011, the unemployment rate in Nauru had significantly decreased to 23%, reflecting some improvement in employment conditions.
• The main industries driving Nauru’s economy include phosphate mining, offshore banking, and the production of coconut-based products.
• Electricity production and consumption in Nauru, primarily generated from fossil fuels, were approximately 30 gigawatt-hours (GWh) as of the year 2000.
• Agriculture does not constitute a major source of employment in Nauru, with coconuts being the principal agricultural product cultivated.

---|---

* Exports - valued at US$30 million (2018). Fish, calcium phosphates, low-voltage protection equipment, air conditioners, leather apparel. Major trading partners include Thailand 34%, Australia 16%, United States 13%, and South Korea 10%.
* Imports - valued at US$90 million (2018). Refined petroleum, construction vehicles, tug boats, poultry meats, cars. Major partners are Taiwan 52% and Australia 28%.
